CatDescriptText: Robert Heyman, was part of the "Pittsburghers Speak Up" column published in Pittsburgh Courier newspaper, June 20, 1959, pg. A1 with question: "In warning against attempting to assure the civil rights of Americans by passing "too many punitive laws," President Eisenhower told the recent National Conference on Civil Rights in Washington, D.C., that: 'I have little faith in ability of statute law to change human hearts to eliminate prejudice. All we can do is hold the line, and wait for a change in mental conditions.'  What do you think of his statement about the problem?" Answer reads: "I think that most of the success depends on the person himself being ready to treat everybody fairly.  Really, a law is not needed."
TitMainTitle: Portrait of Robert Heyman wearing dark button down collared shirt with square pattern, short sleeves, and breast pocket, standing in front of man wearing dark suit and bow tie, leaning against building with large dark sign, building and pedestrians on left in background
